definition:
Given two topological spaces $X$ and $Y$, their [*join,*]{} denoted by
$X\star Y,$ is defined to be the quotient space
$$X\star Y := X{\times}[0,1]{\times}Y/\sim,$$ where the equivalence
relation $\sim$ is generated by $$\begin{aligned}
(x,0,y_1)& \sim (x,0,y_2) &\text{for any}\, x\in X,\, y_1,y_2\in Y,\, \text{and}\\
(x_1,1,y)& \sim (x_2,1,y) &\text{for any}\, y\in Y,\, x_1,x_2\in X.\end{aligned}$$

Intuitively, $X\star Y$ is formed by taking the disjoint union of the
two spaces and attaching a line segment joining every point in $X$ to
every point in $Y.$

Some examples:

-   The join of a space $X$ with a one-point space is called the *cone*
    of $X$.

-   The join of the spheres $S^n$ and $S^m$ is the sphere $S^{n+m+1}$.
